_header: A thousand times have I heard men tell
Note:
See Sherbo (1982)
XSherbo, Arthur. “A Lost Ms of Chaucer’s Legend of Good Women?” Studies in Bibliography 35 (1982): 154-5 for arguments for a lost MS; Ringler Jr. (1988)
XRingler Jr., William A. Bibliography and Index of English Verse Printed 1476-1558. London: Mansell, 1988, TP 50.5.
_description: Chaucer, Legend of Good Women — 2723 lines in couplets (ends unfinished)

BodArcSelB24.First Lines:
A thousand tymes haue I herd men telleThat there is Ioy In heuen
                    and peyn In helle…
BodArcSelB24.Last Lines:
…Till sche was take and fettred In prisounThis tale is said to
                    this conclusioun
BodArcSelB24.Note: Lacks lines 2551-2616; alpha group of witnesses.
BodArcSelB24.Attributed Author:
And thus ended Chaucere the legendis of ladyis (f.
                    191v)
BodArcSelB24.Attributed Title:
Here begynnis the legendes of ladyes (f. 152v); Here endis the
                    prolog of the ;egendis of good wommen (f. 161); And thus ended Chaucere the
                    legendis of ladyis (f. 191v)
BodArcSelB24.Facsimiles:
Boffey,  Julia,  and  A. S. G. Edwards, eds.  
             Chaucer, Works. Bodleian Library MS Arch Selden B.24: Facsimile
                Edition.
         Cambridge: D. S. Brewer, 1995.

Furnivall,  Frederick James,

             A Parallel-Text Edition of Chaucer’s Minor Poems.
             3 vols. 
             Chaucer Society
         1st. ser. 21, 57, 58. London: Trübner, n.d. repr. New York and
            London: Johnson, 1967. 
Sisam,  Celia,  and  Kenneth Sisam, eds.  
             The Oxford Book of Medieval English Verse.
         Oxford: Clarendon, 1970: 313.

Bod638.First Lines:
A Thowsand sithes I haue herd tellTher ys ioy in hevin & peyn
                    in hell…
Bod638.Last Lines:
…and then she was kaught & fetryd in prycounthis tale ys
                    seide for this conclusioun
Bod638.Attributed Title: The Prologe of ix good women (f. 48)

BodFair16.First Lines:
A thousande tymes I haue herd tellether ys Ioy in heuene and peyne
                    in helle…
BodFair16.Last Lines:
…And til she was kaught and fetred in prisonThis tale ys sayde
                    for this conclusion
BodFair16.Attributed Title: The prologe of ix goode Wymmen (f. 83)

BodRawC86.First Lines:
Glorie and honowre virgill mantuainBere thi name & I shall as I
                    can…
BodRawC86.Last Lines:
…But who will haue all this better in myndeRede ovide & In
                    hym ye shall it fynde
BodRawC86.Note: Complaint of Dido only; alpha group of witnesses.
BodRawC86.Attributed Title:
The complaynte of dido (added by later hand of the sixteenth century, f.
                    113); Explicit þe complaint of Dido (scribe, f. 119v)
BodRawC86.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             Odd Texts of the Minor Poems.
             2 vols. 
             Chaucer Society
         1st ser. 23, 60. London: Trübner, 1868, 1880; repr. New York and
            London: Johnson, 1967.

BodTan346.First Lines:
A thousand tymes I hau [he]rd men tellThat ther is ioy in heuen
                    & peyne in hell…
BodTan346.Last Lines:
…And til she was caughte and fetyrde in prysonThis tale is sey
                    for this conclusion
BodTan346.Attributed Title:
The complaynte of dido (added by later hand of the sixteenth century, f.
                    113); Explicit þe complaint of Dido (scribe, f. 119v)
BodTan346.Facsimiles:
Robinson,  Pamela. 
             “Introduction.” 
             Manuscript Tanner 346: A Facsimile.
         Norman, OK: Pilgrim, and Woodbridge: Boydell and Brewer, 1980.

CULFf16.First Lines:
At babilone whilom fil it þusthe wych towne the quene
                    Semiramuslet dychene all a boute & wallys makeffull hey of arde
                    tylys wele y bake…
CULFf16.Last Lines:
…Here may ȝe seen whate louere so he beA woman dar &
                    kan as wele as sche he
CULFf16.Attributed Title: Explicit Pyramus & tesbeNomen scriptoris  nicholaus plenus amoris (f. 67v)
CULFf16.Facsimiles:
Beadle,  Richard,  and  Alfred E. B. Owen.  
             The Findern Manuscript: Cambridge University Library MS. F.1.6.
         London: Scolar Press, 1977.

            London: Johnson, 1967.

CULGg427.First Lines:
A Thousent sythis haue I herd men telleThat there is Ioye in heuene
                    & peyne in helle…
CULGg427.Last Lines:
…Til she was caught & fetered In prysounThis tale is seyd
                    for this conclusioun
CULGg427.Note: Nineteenth-century transcript by Henry Bradshaw in Cambridge UK,  Cambridge University Library Addit. 2793, pp. 1-49; alpha group of witnesses.

CamMagPep2006.First Lines:
A Thowsand tymes I have herd telleThat ther is ioye in heven and
                    peyn in hell…
CamMagPep2006.Last Lines:
…And wyt thy counterfeted peyn and wooAnd thow wer not fals to
                    oon but þow wer fals to twoo
CamMagPep2006.Note:
Lacks lines 706-76 and ends line 1377; alpha group of
                    witnesses.
CamMagPep2006.Facsimiles:
Edwards,  A. S. G. 
             “Introduction.” 
             Manuscript Pepys 2006: A Facsimile. Magdalen College,
                Cambridge.
         Norman, OK: Pilgrim, and [Woodbridge, Suffolk]: Boydell and Brewer,
            1985.

            Johnson, 1967.

CamTCC599.First Lines:
A thousand tymes haue I herd men tellThat ther ys ioy in heuyn and
                    peyne in hellAnd I acorde me well that hyt ys soBut neuertheles yet
                    woll I well also…
CamTCC599.Last Lines:
…Tyll she was caught and fetered in peysounThys tale ys sayde
                    for thys conclusyon
CamTCC599.Attributed Title: Here begynneth the Boke called the legend of Ladyes (f. 114)
CamTCC599.Facsimiles:
Fletcher,  Bradford Y. 
             “Introduction.” 
             Manuscript Trinity R.3.19. A Facsimile.
         Norman, OK: Pilgrim, 1987. 

Digital Facsimile of Trinity College Cambridge MS R.3.19.
         https://mss-cat.trin.cam.ac.uk/Manuscript/R.3.19.

            London: Johnson, 1967.

BLAdd9832.First Lines:
A thousand tymes haue I herd men telleThat ther is Ioye in hevyn
                    And payne in hell…
BLAdd9832.Last Lines:
…he shall be holpyn how so that we doffodera Aunswerd Iwisse
                    me is ryght wo
BLAdd9832.Note:
Lines 1-1985, interleaved with William Bonham’s ed. of Chaucer,
                    1542, which continues as ff. 43-47; alpha group of witnesses.
BLAdd9832.Attributed Author: compyled by M: Geffrey Chaucer (f. 2, in later hand)
BLAdd9832.Attributed Title: The legende of Goode Womenne (f. 2, in later hand)
BLAdd9832.Editions:
Pegge,  Samuel. 
             “Letter signed ‘Paul Gemsage’ [=anagram for Samuel Pegge;
                ‘Gemsage’ a misprint for ‘Gemsege’].” 
             Gentleman’s Magazine
         (1758): 260-2:  (but see Sherbo (1982)
XSherbo,  Arthur. 
             “A Lost Ms of Chaucer’s Legend of Good Women?” 
             Studies in Bibliography
         35 (1982): 154-5).
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.

            Johnson, 1967.

BLAdd12524.First Lines:
…Ne shulde hyr neuer falsen nyght nor dayTo been hyr hysbonde
                    till he lyff may…
BLAdd12524.Last Lines:
…And till she wes fettred & put in presouneThys taile ys
                    seide to this conclusioune
BLAdd12524.Note: Begins imperfectly, line 1640; alpha group of witnesses.
BLAdd12524.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             A Supplementary Parallel-Text Edition of Chaucer’s Minor
                Poems.
             2 vols. 
             Chaucer Society
         1st ser. 22, 59. London: Trübner, n.d.; repr. New York and London:
            Johnson, 1967.

BLAdd28617.First Lines:
She that for hire housbonde chees to dyeAnd she to goon to helle
                    rather than he…
BLAdd28617.Last Lines:
…Tyl she was take and ffetred in prisonThis tale ys seyde ffor
                    this conclusion
BLAdd28617.Note: Fragments only: begins line 513; alpha group of witnesses.
BLAdd28617.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             Odd Texts of the Minor Poems.
             2 vols. 
             Chaucer Society
         1st ser. 23, 60. London: Trübner, 1868, 1880; repr. New York and
            London: Johnson, 1967.
